The platform embeds policy controls, approval workflows, and realâtime alerts to manage spending proactively, helping finance teams reduce manual tasks and improve visibility. It integrates with ERP and HRIS systems, syncs transactions reliably, and supports global operations across multiple currencies. Leveraging AI, Ramp automates expense submission, invoice processing, data coding, and costâsaving insights. Businesses report accelerated monthâend closing, fewer errors, and more transparent spending with the platform.

news.title: Fintech Ramp valued at US$16 billion in late-stage funding round
Ramp Raises $200M Series E at $16B Valuation as Companies of All Sizes Choose AI-Powered Finance Platform
Meet PostHog, A Startup That Just Raised A $70M Series D Led By Stripe From A Single Tweet

Eric Glyman.wikipedia_summary:
Ramp Business Corporation is a Manhattan-based multinational financial technology company that offers corporate charge cards, expense management, and bill-payment software. The company is headquartered in the Flatiron District of New York City with additional offices in Miami and San Francisco.
As of March 2025, Ramp was valued at $13 billion and processing $55 billion in payments annually.

Gene Lee.wikipedia_summary: Cantopop (a contraction of "Cantonese pop music") is a genre of pop music sung in Cantonese. Cantopop is also used to refer to the cultural context of its production and consumption. The genre began in the 1970s and became associated with Hong Kong popular music from the middle of the decade.

news_summary: Ramp was valued at US$16 billion in its latest funding round. It offers digital and artificial intelligence-based services. The round also saw participation from Thrive Capital, D1 Capital Partners, General Catalyst and GIC. After a years-long funding slump, fintech is attracting interest from investors. Ramp enables tens of billions in purchases annually and serves over 40,000 customers. Its customers include e-commerce platform Shopify, commercial real estate services and investment firm CBRE. The latest round brings Ramp’s total equity financing to US$1.4 billion. Ramp has saved customers $10 billion and 27.5 million hours. The company currently powers over $80 billion in annualized purchase volume across card transactions and bill payments. For the fifth time, a Ramp funding round was led by Founders Fund – the company's first and largest investor. Ramp's product line includes corporate cards and expense management, bill payments, procurement, travel booking, and treasury. Half of Ramp customers use two or more products across its platform. rves more than 40,000 companies, including CBRE, Shopify, Anduril, Notion, Cursor, Vercel, Barry's and MAGNA-TILES. Ramp is your net for catching hours and dollars, it's 'quiet efficiency' The less you have to think about it, the better we're doing our job. A ramp is quite literally a simple machine; like the lever or pulley, it helps you do more work with less force. Ramp has doubled the percent of employee expense reports fully completed and coded without humans needing to lift a finger. Book a hotel and our AI will automatically rebook it if the price drops. We launched 300+ features and made it easier to contact Ramp; still, customers contacted us 34% less often. 40,000 businesses across every sector are choosing Ramp to reclaim their time and money. Construction One reduced their AP team's time spent on monthly close by 75%, saving them 360 hours. Poshmark hit their free cash flow goals 5 months ahead of schedule by redirecting their team's energy toward strategic projects. In 2025 alone, we've shipped 270 features. All were quietly built with the help of AI. It works, you don't notice it. And that's the way we like it. We spend over 50% of our payroll on research and development. It's also why we have more IOI and IMO medalists on our team than most countries. Ramp isn't 'with the help of AI', it's 'done for you and we don't mention it' AI. PostHog, which aims to help developers build “successful products,” quietly announced it had raised $70 million in a Series D funding round led by digital payments giant Stripe. PostHog raised $107 million in a Series D round. The company's new valuation is roughly double its valuation at the time of its $15 million Series B in 2021. Stripe co-founder and CEO Patrick Collison tweeted about PostHog’s site “being cool” PostHog has raised $9 million in its first two rounds of funding. The company is working on a new version of its software called PostHog 2.0. The software is designed to make it easier for developers to build data-driven apps. It is expected to be available by the end of the year. Hawkins and Glaser started working on PostHog during Y Combinator’s Winter 2020 batch. The company focused on just open source software (vs. revenue) for the first year and a half. The full-stack approach highlights the strength of their approach, Hawkins says. PostHog is using artificial intelligence to help teams better understand and work with customers. Its Max AI platform is generally available as an open beta. Users include Y Combinator, 1Password, Mistrial AI, Airbus and Eleven Labs. PostHog has “multiple $10s of millions of ARR and 3x year-over-year growth,” Hawkins says. Since its 2010 inception, Stripe has invested in dozens of companies, per Crunchbase data. In February, it announced a tender offer in which investors would buy shares from past and present employees at a valuation of $91.5 billion. It has also acquired at least 17 companies, according to Crunchbase.
